repository.corpname: Special Collections Research Center, The George Washington University

did.physloc: Materials may be stored off-site, and may require additional retrieval time. Please contact the Special Collections Research Center for more information.
did.abstract: This collection contains correspondence, clippings, article drafts, and subject files collected by Richard T. Gibson from 1948 to 2004. Richard T. Gibson (1931-) is an American expatriate journalist, international correspondent, and author based in London. He is the author of African Liberation Movements (1972), was a member of the black expatriate literary community in Paris in the late 1950s, and was a founder of the Fair Play for Cuba Committee in the 1960s. He maintained active personal and professional correspondence from the 1960s to the 2000s, some of which contains information regarding leftist and anticolonial movements in the United States, United Kingdom, Europe, and Africa.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Richard T. Gibson (1931-) is an American expatriate journalist, international correspondent, and author based in London. He is the author of African Liberation Movements (1972), which describes movements against white-minority rule across Africa, including South Africa, Rhodesia (Zimbabwe), Angola, and Mozambique. He worked as a reporter for the Philadelphia Afro-American, the Christian Science Monitor, Agence France-Presse, CBS, Revolution Africaine, Negro Press International, and Tuesday Publications, Inc. He was a member of the black expatriate literary community in Paris in the late 1950s, and was a founder of the Fair Play for Cuba Committee in the 1960s. He maintained active personal and professional correspondence from the 1960s to the 2000s, some of which contains information regarding leftist and anticolonial movements in the United States, United Kingdom, Europe, and Africa.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Please cite unpublished materials in the following way:
Please provide the title and date of item, catalog number (if applicable it will be found written on the folder), name of the collection, name of the repository, and location of the repository.

Example: James Oglethorpe to the Trustees, 13 January 1876, RG0001 Series 1, Box 4, Folder 3. Records of the Board of Trustees, Special Collections Research Center, Gelman Library, The George Washington University, Washington, D.C.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Some material may be copyrighted or restricted. It is the patron's obligation to determine and satisfy copyright or other case restrictions when publishing or otherwise distributing materials found in the collections.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This collection is open for research.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into four series: Correspondence, Publications, Subject files, and Photographs.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection contains correspondence, clippings, article drafts, and subject files collected by Richard T. Gibson from 1948 to 2004. The material was created and collected as part of Gibson's work as a journalist, publisher's agent, and activist, and includes material relating to liberation movements in Africa, and Marxist-Leninist and Communist parties in the United States, United Kingdom, and Europe. Individuals of note represented in this collection include Amiri Baraka, Julian Mayfield, Lyle Stuart, Jacques Verges, and Robert F. Williams.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series includes personal as well as professional correspondence from 1964 to 2003, particularly regarding liberation movements in Africa, and Marxist-Leninist and Communist parties in the United States, United Kingdom, and Europe. In addition, some correspondence relates to Gibson's work as an agent of the U.S. publisher Lyle Stuart, and some involves the case of black nationalist Robert F. Williams. Finally, the series contains some personal correspondence between Gibson and his family. The correspondence in this series is primarily in English, with some in French and a small amount in Italian and German.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged chronologically, except for correspondence on a few specific topics and individuals, which are filed together by topic at the end of the chronological files.

did.unittitle: Correspondence -- Institute of Race Relation/OUP: "African Liberation Movements"
Correspondence re: "Prelude to a Movement" documentary film
Correspondence with Lyle Stuart -- FBI file
Correspondence and article on Robert F. Williams

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains magazine, newspaper, and newsletter clippings with articles by or about Gibson as well as materials Gibson collected on the subject of African liberation movements. These date from 1958 to 2004. It also includes draft articles and essays by Gibson, as well as early journals, which date from 1948 to 1954.

did.unittitle: "Friends of the Oppressed," or the New Bien-Pensants

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This small series contains administrative files, clippings, and legal documents that Gibson filed together by topic. It includes material on prominent anticolonialist Jacques Vergès, civil rights activist Julian Mayfield, and black nationalist Robert F. Williams, and dates from 1965 to 2002. The material is primarily in English, with some in French and a small amount in Italian and German.

did.unittitle: FBI file -- Lyle Stuart, Richard Gibson, FPCC
Robert F. Williams material for Ronald J. Stephens

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains photographs and slides of Richard T. Gibson, his family, and his travels. It includes family photographs from the 1920s to the 1970s as well as photographs from a visit to Cuba in 1960. Many early family photographs are labeled, but later photographs and slides are not.
